messages.content:
For example you might want to define a node called `OrganizationManufacturer` and then on the device node you could do cardinality one relationship to it like so:

```
    relationships:
      - name: manufacturer
        peer: OrganizationManufacturer
        cardinality: one
        kind: Attribute
        optional: false
```
I'm really having a blast with this tool!
To see an example schema you might want to check out our schema library for inspiration: https://github.com/opsmill/schema-library/blob/main/base/dcim.yml

messages.content:
of course! You can have attributes which are fields of a node or you can define relationships which peer with another node kind. 

This doc covers this: https://docs.infrahub.app/guides/create-schema#step-2-add-relationships-between-nodes

embeds.title: Creating a schema | Infrahub Documentation
embeds.description: This guide shows you how to create a new schema file for Infrahub. You'll learn to define data structures and relationships using a network device example with interfaces.

messages.content: The UV command just allows you to run infrahubctl without setting up a project / installing our SDK first

What is the goal of this part ? >>  "uv tool run --from 'infrahub-sdk[ctl]' infrahubctl repository init <directory>"
I mean what are the benefits of this ? Without this option, where does the files would be stored ?

By the way i have a new instance of infrahub which is working. 

(infrahub) {25-09-24 18:25}jeysrv10:/opt/infrahub jeyriku% ls -la 
total 40
drwxr-xr-x  9 jeyriku jeyriku 4096 sept. 24 18:04 .
drwxr-xr-x  8 root    root    4096 sept. 24 17:36 ..
drwxrwxr-x  2 jeyriku jeyriku 4096 sept. 24 17:51 bin
drwxrwxr-x  2 jeyriku jeyriku 4096 sept. 24 17:46 docs
drwxrwxr-x  4 jeyriku jeyriku 4096 sept. 24 17:40 include
***drwxrwxr-x 16 jeyriku jeyriku 4096 sept. 24 17:39 infrahub***
***drwxrwxr-x 12 jeyriku jeyriku 4096 sept. 24 18:05 jeyinfrahub***
drwxrwxr-x  3 jeyriku jeyriku 4096 sept. 24 17:37 lib
lrwxrwxrwx  1 jeyriku jeyriku    3 sept. 24 17:37 lib64 -> lib
-rw-rw-r--  1 jeyriku jeyriku  173 sept. 24 17:37 pyvenv.cfg
drwxrwxr-x  4 jeyriku jeyriku 4096 sept. 24 17:40 share

In the home directory i have both most important folders which are the infrahub app folder and the customized folder as advised which i created with "uv tool run --from 'infrahub-sdk[ctl]' infrahubctl repository init /opt/infrahub/jeyinfrahub".

What could be the next steps beside creating my first branch and schema ? (in the meantime i also watch your videos, schema part 1,2,3).

referenced_message.content:
We do however provide the ability to setup a repository that contains a lot of of information and boiler plate which can be found here: https://docs.infrahub.app/topics/developer-guide#initializing-an-infrahub-repository

Using the command:

`uv tool run --from 'infrahub-sdk[ctl]' infrahubctl repository init <directory>`

Will set you up with a repository which will provide you with some helpers to start and stop infrahub locally:

```
uv sync --all-packages
source .venv/bin/activate
invoke start
```

embeds.title: Developer Guide | Infrahub Documentation
embeds.description: Infrahub support various form of extensibility that rely on users providing their own code that then will be executed by Infrahub.

Hello, 

Infrahub has many different ways to get started you can see an overview of the Infrahub platform here: https://docs.infrahub.app/getting-started/overview

There is an installation guide that has many different installation instructions that best suit your needs: https://docs.infrahub.app/guides/installation
